data.title: Palin confirms Christian version of memoir – Winnipeg Free Press
data.text:
Hey there, time traveller!

This article was published 04/07/2009 (5534 days ago), so information in it may no longer be current.

Alaska Governor Sarah Palin has confirmed that a special Christian version of her 2010 memoir will be published.

That edition will include more information about Palin’s faith and her religious views.

Palin received an advance has rumoured to be near to $10 million. She has chosen Lynn Vincent as her co-author. Vincent is a writer with the conservative Christian magazine World.

The special edition will be published by Zondervan, HarperCollins Christian publishing imprint. HarperCollins will publish the regular version. Its title is not confirmed.

“ö “ö “ö

The latest round of inductions to the Order of Canada included seven writers and publishers were honoured.

On Canada Day, Gov.-Gen. Michaëlle Jean appointed to the order B.C.’s Jack Hodgins, P.E.I.’s David Helwig and Quebecers Wajdi Mouawad, Claude LeBouthillier and Jean O’Neil.

Coach House Books founder Stan Bevington and Giller Prize founder Jack Rabinovitch also received the honour. Rabinovitch was also named an Officer of the Order.

“ö “ö “ö

Manitoba MLA Christine Melnick will be accepting new and gently used books for her Share the Magic program at the Aug. 5 Winnipeg Goldeyes game.

Melnick is the minister of water stewardship. Share the Magic is a program that distributes books to Manitobans who do not have easy access to libraries.

The Association of Manitoba Book Publishers is providing volunteers to man the tables at the game.

“ö “ö “ö

The winner of the Israeli Sapir Prize for Literature has been stripped of the honour after conflict of interest issues were raised.

Alon Hilu had won the $45,000 prize for his novel The House of Dajani.

According to one report the editor of Hilu’s work was the niece of one of the judges.

Finalist Amnon Dankner also had to return $7,500 he received for Aunt Eva, His Days and Nights. In that case the work was apparently dedicated to one of the judges.

The Sapir Prize is Israel’s most prestigious book award.

“ö “ö “ö

U.S. writer David McKenzie has won the grand prize in the 2009 Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest for bad writing.

The contest is sponsored by the San Jose State University. Entrants submit bad openings to works in categories including spy stories, adventures and vile puns.

McKenzie won for an opening that began, “Folks say that if you listen real close at the height of the full moon … “

The annual contest is named for the U.K.’s Edward George Earl Bulwer-Lytton. In 1830 he famously began a novel with the sentence “It was a dark and stormy night.”
